questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with HIV infection comes to the emergency department because of fever and multiple skin lesions for 1 week. She also has nausea, anorexia, and abdominal pain. The skin lesions are nonpruritic and painless. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years and drinks 2 beers daily. She has been using intravenous crack cocaine for 6 years. She appears ill. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. Her BMI is 19 kg/m2. Examination shows track marks on both cubital fossae. There are white patches on her palate that can be scraped off. There are several red papules on the face and trunk. Her CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 98/mm3. Biopsy of a skin lesion shows vascular proliferation and small black bacteria on Warthin-Starry stain. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Combination therapy with pyrimethamine and sulfadiazine for a minimum of 4–6 weeks is the treatment of choice for toxoplasmosis. Leucovorin (folinic acid) is also administered to alleviate the myelotoxic side effects of pyrimethamine. Although toxoplasmosis is a common infection in patients with HIV infection (particularly with a CD4+ T-lymphocyte count < 100 cells/mm3), it generally causes encephalitis. Skin lesions would not occur in association with toxoplasmosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Intralesional administration of vinblastine is a first-line treatment option for Kaposi sarcoma, an important differential diagnosis to consider in patients with HIV who have skin lesions and concurrent abdominal symptoms. Lesions in Kaposi sarcoma and bacillary angiomatosis can be very similar in appearance, making it difficult to differentiate them. However, a biopsy of a Kaposi sarcoma lesion would show spindle-shaped cells, leukocyte infiltration, and angiogenesis, and Warthin-Starry stain would be negative, making this diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

The purple-bluish lesions, seen on the heel of this HIV-positive patient, are multiple Kaposi sarcoma. The lesion on the left side is elevated, while the other lesions are patches. The causative agent is HHV-8.

C) INCORRECT:

Combination therapy with azithromycin and ethambutol is the treatment of choice for Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infections, which are common in patients with advanced immunocompromise due to HIV infection (usually only occurs if CD4+ T-lymphocyte count < 50/mm3). Although MAC infection could explain this patient's constitutional symptoms and gastrointestinal symptoms, it generally manifests as a disseminated infection with respiratory involvement (cough) and generalized lymphadenopathy. Skin lesions are not expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Caspofungin is used to treat systemic candidiasis, which typically affects immunocompromised patients and manifests with symptoms of disseminated disease (e.g. gastrointestinal involvement, skin lesions, and constitutional symptoms). However, the appearance of the skin lesions and biopsy results are not consistent with this diagnosis. Although this patient likely has oral candidiasis, caspofungin is not considered first-line therapy.

E) CORRECT:

Erythromycin is the first-line drug for the treatment of bacillary angiomatosis. Patients should generally take oral erythromycin for 3 months. Alternatively, oral doxycycline can be administered for a similar duration of time. In patients with HIV, if not yet initiated, antiretroviral therapy should also be started.

The white patches on the patient's palate that can be scraped off are a typical sign of oral thrush. In addition to the treatment of the bacillary angiomatosis, oral thrush should be treated with a topical antifungal agent (e.g., nystatin). On its own (in the absence of candida esophagitis), oral thrush is not an AIDS-defining condition.

F) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) are used to treat pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP), which typically occurs in patients with HIV infection and a CD4+ T-lymphocyte count < 200/mm3. Although this patient's constitutional symptoms and significantly decreased CD4+ T-lymphocyte count may suggest PCP, signs of pneumonia (dyspnea, cough) would be expected. Moreover, skin lesions are not suggestive of PCP. TMP/SMX is not effective in the management of bacillary angiomatosis.

G) INCORRECT:

Nitazoxanide is used in the treatment of cryptosporidiosis, which could be responsible for this patient's gastrointestinal symptoms, however, it usually also causes protracted diarrhea and does not explain this patient's skin lesions.
questions.hint: This patient with HIV presents with constitutional symptoms and angiomatous skin lesions with bacteria detected on Warthin-Starry stain, which makes bacillary angiomatosis the most likely diagnosis. Bacillary angiomatosis can also manifest with gastrointestinal lesions, which cause abdominal pain, nausea, anorexia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of chills and numerous skin lesions for 1 week. He has also had watery diarrhea, nausea, and abdominal pain for the past 2 weeks. The skin lesions are nonpruritic and painless. He was diagnosed with HIV infection approximately 20 years ago. He has not taken any medications for over 5 years. He sleeps in homeless shelters and parks. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows several bright red, friable nodules on his face, trunk, and extremities. The liver is palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 90/mm3. A rapid plasma reagin test is negative. Abdominal ultrasonography shows hepatomegaly and a single intrahepatic 1.0 x 1.2-cm hypodense lesion. Biopsy of a skin lesion shows vascular proliferation and abundant neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cryptosporidiosis is an AIDS-defining condition that manifests with chronic, watery diarrhea as well as nausea and abdominal pain. Liver involvement (e.g., hepatitis) does occur in some cases, but cutaneous lesions are not characteristic of this condition.

B) INCORRECT:

HHV-8 virus infection causes Kaposi sarcoma (KS), an AIDS-defining condition that manifests with solitary or multiple bluish-brown, painless plaques or nodules. With disease progression, KS may disseminate to other organs (e.g., the liver). However, in addition to vascular proliferation, biopsy findings would also show spindle-shaped cells. Moreover, a biopsy sample in a patient with KS typically shows abundant lymphocytes, not neutrophils.

C) INCORRECT:

Treponema pallidum infection causes syphilis. Patients with secondary syphilis may present with nodular lesions. However, vascular proliferation is not a typical histopathological finding and the patient has tested negative for rapid plasma reagin (RPR), which together make syphilis an unlikely diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Localized Candida infection causes several conditions, including oral thrush, skin infections, Candida esophagitis (an AIDS-defining condition), and invasive disease (systemic candidiasis). Systemic infection can occasionally involve the liver. However, vascular proliferation and abundant neutrophils would not be expected on biopsy.

E) INCORRECT:

Infection with Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC), an AIDS-defining condition, is the most common opportunistic bacterial infection in patients with AIDS. However, MAC typically causes systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss, lymphadenopathy) and very rarely manifests in patients with a CD4+ count > 50/mm3.

F) CORRECT:

Bartonella henselae infection causes bacillary angiomatosis, which primarily occurs in patients who are severely immunocompromised (especially those with AIDS and a CD4 count < 100). Bacillary angiomatosis typically manifests with solitary or multiple cutaneous papules and nodules that are red, flesh-colored, or colorless and bleed easily. Visceral organ involvement, which is uncommon, can manifest with abdominal pain, diarrhea, weight loss, and hepatosplenomegaly. The diagnosis is confirmed if a biopsy of the affected tissue shows vascular proliferation and neutrophilic infiltrate and positivity on Warthin-Starry staining. Treatment is antibiotic therapy (erythromycin or doxycycline).
questions.hint: Cats are the main host of this pathogen, which is most commonly transmitted through bites, scratches, and fleas.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with HIV infection comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. The patient is experiencing homelessness and reports that he has not been taking his medications regularly. Examination shows multiple large, firm violaceous nodules, which erode easily, on his arms, legs, and trunk. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 90/mm3. Treatment with oral erythromycin is begun. Three months later, the lesions have resolved. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mycobacterium tuberculosis is the causal pathogen of tuberculosis, for which HIV-infected patients are at higher risk, especially when CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is < 500/mm3, as seen here. However, in immunocompromised patients, cutaneous tuberculosis typically manifests with scrofuloderma, orificial tuberculosis, miliary cutaneous tuberculosis, or tuberculous gummas; the large firm violaceous nodules in this patient suggest a different diagnosis. Moreover, tuberculosis is treated with a multidrug regimen of rifampin (or rifabutin), isoniazid, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide rather than a single-drug therapy with erythromycin.
Image Description:

Axilla and arm of a child with HIV infection and tuberculosis

The region around the axillary lymph nodes shows two ulcerated lesions, which are firm to touch.

These findings are typical clinical features of scrofuloderma, which usually heals leaving a scar.

B) CORRECT:

In a patient with HIV infection and a CD4+ T-lymphocyte count < 100/mm3, multiple firm violaceous nodules or papules that erode easily and resolve after prolonged treatment with erythromycin or doxycycline suggest bacillary angiomatosis (BA), which is most commonly caused by Bartonella henselae. Patients infected with B. henselae usually have a history of contact with cats because the pathogen is typically transmitted from the feces of cat fleas via a cat scratch. Immunocompetent individuals remain asymptomatic or develop only a self-limiting infection with fever and granulomatous regional lymphadenopathy (cat scratch disease). Immunocompromised patients, however, can develop BA as a result of hematogenous dissemination.

BA can also be caused by Bartonella quintana, which is mainly transmitted by body lice (common in homeless populations). Kaposi sarcoma (KS), another condition that occurs in immunocompromised patients, is also a vascular lesion like BA and can have a similar appearance. These two conditions are differentiated by biopsy. KS is associated with a lymphocytic rather than neutrophilic infiltrate.
Image Description:

Two angioma-like lesions with a surrounding erythematous halo are visible.

This immunocompromised patient was diagnosed with bacillary angiomatosis due to Bartonella quintana.

C) INCORRECT:

Nocardia brasiliensis is the causal pathogen of nocardiosis, which is more common in immunocompromised patients, such as patients with HIV (especially if CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is < 100/mm3, as seen here). Although N. brasiliensis can cause cutaneous lesions (cutaneous nocardiosis), patients usually present with cellulitis or purulent erythematous nodules rather than multiple large violaceous nodules. Moreover, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, not erythromycin, is the appropriate antibiotic therapy for cutaneous nocardiosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of skin infections such as impetigo, folliculitis, and abscesses. However, none of these skin infections would typically present with large violaceous nodules that erode easily, as seen in this patient. Moreover, erythromycin is not used to treat S. aureus infections because of the high incidence of S. aureus resistance against this antibiotic. Rather, skin and soft tissue infections caused by S. aureus are treated with nafcillin, dicloxacillin, or oxacillin in the case of MSSA, and in the case of MRSA, e.g., with vancomycin, clindamycin, linezolid, or ceftaroline.

E) INCORRECT:

Human herpesvirus 8 is the causal pathogen of Kaposi sarcoma, a common tumor in patients with HIV infection, especially when CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is < 500/mm3, and would manifest in late stages as multiple cutaneous violaceous nodules, as seen here. However, these would not resolve with erythromycin; rather, they are treated with radiation therapy, intralesional administration of vinblastine, and/or systemic therapy with liposomal anthracyclines (e.g., doxorubicin, daunorubicin) or taxanes (e.g., paclitaxel).

F) INCORRECT:

Coccidioides immitis is the causal pathogen of coccidioidomycosis. Disseminated coccidioidomycosis occurs in immunocompromised individuals, including patients with HIV (especially if CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is < 250/mm3), and can present as multiple cutaneous nodules, as seen here. However, patients with coccidioidomycosis usually have arthralgia and respiratory symptoms before the onset of cutaneous lesions. Moreover, coccidioidomycosis is treated with amphotericin B, itraconazole, and/or fluconazole, rather than erythromycin.
questions.hint: Biopsy of the nodules would show vascular proliferation and neutrophilic infiltrate. The causal pathogen is a gram-negative rod and can be visualized on biopsy using the Warthin-Starry stain.
